subj-group.subject: Symposium on Assets, Incomes and Retirement

title-group.article-title: The Dynamics of Male Retirement Behaviour

abstract.p: This paper uses data from the two waves of the UK Retirement Survey to present a detailed descriptive analysis of the retirement behaviour of older men. The main motivation for doing this is the fall in the employment rates of older men over the last 20 years. A comparison of the labour market behaviour of men with and without an occupational pension suggests that increases in the coverage and levels of occupational pensions may not be enough to explain the long-term trends in labour market behaviour, but that there are important differences in the retirement experiences of the two groups.

p.mixed-citation: See Meghir and Whitehouse (1997) for a discussion of the effects of wages and state benefits on the retirement behaviour of men without occupational pensions.
In all of what follows, 'significant' refers to significance at the 5 per cent level.
This includes those who spontaneously reply that they consider themselves to be semi-retired, although this applies to less than 1.5 per cent of the sample.
These groups are defined according to whether individuals have retained rights to an occupational pension, not by whether they are drawing an occupational pension.
Although there is clearly an issue as to whether individuals reply 'less' when in fact their pension is reduced by — or even by less than — an actuarially fair amount.

It is not always clear what individuals mean when they refer to 'fixed retirement ages', not least because of the degree of divergence between 'fixed retirement ages' and individuals' actual retirement ages. There are (at least) two possible interpretations. One is that individuals may simply be referring to the modal retirement age in the firm they work for. In this case, there is little or no constraint implied by the term 'fixed retirement age'. The second interpretation is that individuals are referring to the age rules of their occupational pension scheme. In this context, the firm may have some degree of influence over the timing of individual retirement decisions through attaching financial penalties to early retirement.
